BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Gradual increase in danger of dry avalanches as the snowfall becomes more intense.
The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects and generally above the tree line. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible.

The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow will fall until the evening above approximately 1200 m. The new snow will be deposited on a crust in particular on east to south to west facing aspects.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Gradual increase in danger of dry avalanches as the snowfall becomes more intense.
The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects and generally above the tree line. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible.

The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow will fall until the evening above approximately 1200 m. The new snow will be deposited on a crust in particular on east to south to west facing aspects.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase from midday.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Gradual increase in danger of dry avalanches as the snowfall becomes more intense. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase in the afternoon.
The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects and generally above the tree line. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible.

The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow will fall until the evening above approximately 1200 m. The new snow will be deposited on a crust in particular on east to south to west facing aspects.

Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the old snowpack on shady slopes. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in high Alpine regions.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase from midday.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Gradual increase in danger of dry avalanches as the snowfall becomes more intense. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase in the afternoon.
The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects and generally above the tree line. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible.

The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow will fall until the evening above approximately 1200 m. The new snow will be deposited on a crust in particular on east to south to west facing aspects.

Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the old snowpack on shady slopes. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in high Alpine regions.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in some places. This snow can be released naturally in all aspects and generally above the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes, and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. Small and medium-sized avalanches are possible.

The wind will be strong at times in some localities.
The wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack at intermediate and high altitudes. These will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. They can be released easily in some places. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Tuesday: 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 1500 m. The new snow will be deposited on a crust in particular on east to south to west facing aspects.

The old snowpack is favourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase on Wednesday. The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in some places. This snow can be released naturally in all aspects and generally above the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes, and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. Small and medium-sized avalanches are possible.

The wind will be strong at times in some localities.
The wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack at intermediate and high altitudes. These will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. They can be released easily in some places. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Tuesday: 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 1500 m. The new snow will be deposited on a crust in particular on east to south to west facing aspects.

The old snowpack is favourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase on Wednesday. The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain easily released wind slabs formed. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to increasing softening of the snowpack over a wide area especially at low and intermediate altitudes. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The snowpack will be moist in the southeast and in the southwest.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The early morning will see favourable conditions generally, but the danger of wet and gliding avalanches will increase later.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In some localities up to 10 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1500 m. As a consequence of the precipitation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the afternoon. Slow warming. As the snowfall level rises gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible. In gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at high altitude large surface-area wind slabs will form. The fresh wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 1600 m rain will fall in some regions. Individual moist and wet avalanches are possible in the afternoon, in particular on steep slopes below approximately 1800 m. The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects and generally at high altitude.
Up to high altitudes rain will fall on Wednesday in some regions. In some localities in some regions up to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Wednesday above approximately 1900 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Up to high altitudes rain will fall on Wednesday in some regions. In some localities 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Wednesday above approximately 1900 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. In many places there is a danger of falling on the hard crust.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence and generally at elevated altitudes. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. In all aspects small and medium-sized avalanches are possible. Avalanches can be released, in particular by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of falling temperatures a crust formed on the surface during the last few days. Individual weak layers exist in the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Intensive precipitation.
Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. Gliding avalanches require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from southerly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form in some places. Caution is to be exercised in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m, as well as adjacent to ridgelines in high Alpine regions. Avalanches are only small but can be released even by a single winter sport participant.

A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can reach medium size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some localities up to 10 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1400 m. The wind will be strong to storm force at times.
Fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
The old snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Wednesday. As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind from southerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs will form. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from southwesterly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in the course of the day. The wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack at intermediate and high altitudes. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is slightly greater.
They can be released easily in some places. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.

The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in some places. Small and medium-sized avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Tuesday: 10 to 15 cm of snow will fall until the evening above approximately 1800 m.
In the western part of the northern flank of the Alps, along the border with France in some regions 10 cm of snow fell on Saturday. The wind was strong.
The weather was cold.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase on Wednesday. The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from southwesterly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in the course of the day. The wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack at intermediate and high altitudes. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is slightly greater.
They can be released easily in some places. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.

The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in some places. Small and medium-sized avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Tuesday: 10 to 15 cm of snow will fall until the evening above approximately 1800 m.
In the western part of the northern flank of the Alps, along the border with France in some regions 10 cm of snow fell on Saturday. The wind was strong.
The weather was cold.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase on Wednesday. The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Moist loose snow slides are possible in isolated cases as before.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The old snowpack will be generally stable. It is homogeneous and its surface has a strong crust. As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from southerly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form in the afternoon in some places, in particular on very steep shady slopes above the tree line, as well as adjacent to ridgelines in high Alpine regions. Mostly avalanches are only small but can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
In addition mostly small loose snow avalanches are possible, in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some localities 5 to 15 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1500 m. The wind will be strong to storm force at times.
Fresh wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects above the tree line.
The old snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Wednesday. As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind from southerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs will form. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding snow requires caution. Wind slabs at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can reach medium size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, mostly small wind slabs formed in isolated cases. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. These places are rather rare and are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.

In addition individual small loose snow avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow has fallen since Saturday in some regions. The wind was strong in some cases.
Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
The old snowpack will be moist below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gliding snow requires caution. Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Wednesday. As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind from southerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found on extremely steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes. Avalanches are small and can mostly only be released by large loads.

In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Only a little snow is now lying. The snowpack will be generally stable. The snowpack is moist and its surface has a crust. The solar radiation will give rise to moistening of the snowpack especially on steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some localities up to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Wednesday. As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from southerly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be in most cases well bonded.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The meteorological conditions will foster a gradual weakening of the snowpack as the day progresses.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. These are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Only isolated mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 1900 m. In gullies and bowls a sometimes precarious avalanche situation will be encountered in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m no snow is lying. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. As a consequence of the precipitation, the likelihood of wet snow slides and avalanches being released will increase a little.
